p: ACE2 is an ectoenzyme anchored to the plasma membrane of the cells of several tissues, especially those of the lower respiratory tract, heart, kidney and gastrointestinal tract [ 15]. Inoculation of the 2019 nCoV onto surface layers of human airway epithelial cells inÂ vitro causes cytopathic effects and cessation of the cilia movements [ 16]. SARS-CoV highly replicates in the type I and II pneumocytes and in enterocytes, and the SARS-induced down-regulation of ACE2 receptors in lung epithelium contributes to the pathogenesis of acute lung injury and subsequent ARDS [ 15, 17]. Whether the higher receptor affinity for ACE2 of SARS-CoV-2 than SARS-CoV could lead to a more severe lung involvement in COVID-19 than in SARS requires further investigation.
